fullText:
When a character in the new musical "The Heart of Rock and Roll" tries to convince his ex to leave her job at a factory that makes shipping materials, he is stunned: "Oh, my god. It's cardboard!"

But there can be real appeal to the humblest of materials â€” and the same can be said of this unpretentious, silly and, in the end, rather fun show. For all the familiar jukebox musical templates of thin characters, unsurprising plot developments and oldie pop/rock songs shoehorned into the narrative, there's something to be said for simple packaging that knows what it is and does it well.

The show, which premiered in 2018 at The Old Globe, features Jonathan A. Abrams' original script (story by Tyler Mitchell and Abrams), which is "inspired by the songs of Huey Lewis and the News," the mainstream '80s group known for hook-filled pop/rock songs sung by its raspy-voiced, likable-guy lead singer.
showScoreExcerpt: "Humor and brightness is what fuels this engine"

keyPhrases.quote: there's something to be said for simple packaging that knows what it is and does it well
pleasant middle which neither offends nor inspires, just entertains
it doesn't really matter that it thinks inside the box. After all, cardboard has its uses

llmScore.reasoning: Claude: The critic finds genuine entertainment value in this 'unpretentious, silly and rather fun show' despite acknowledging its formulaic nature and thin plotting, ultimately endorsing it as effective crowd-pleasing entertainment. | GPT-4o-mini: The review indicates a generally entertaining experience with some fun moments, but also highlights significant weaknesses in the plot and music, leading to a mixed-positive recommendation.
